bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 2, 1899

div1.p: Reed tells Kean that their efforts to have Reed's son, Lawrence, scheduled for a board of review for promotion have failed, and thanks him for all his kindness to Lawrence. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 2, 1899
div1.p:
Your very
kind letter of March 26th has
been received and was much
appreciated. I thank you very
much for your efforts in
behalf of the boy's promotion.
I may as well tell you, however,
that nothing more can be
done, at present, in that
direction. You, for the moment,
forget that only political in-
fluence is of any value. I have,
at considerable loss of time
and independence, done my damndest
to get L. ordered before a
Board, but the Adjutant General
will not listen to it. I have
now made up my mind that
he must wait till next April
when his length of service will
entitle him to an examination.
He will then win, if he can
pass the Board. The Dept.
would not make such a rul-
ing as that spoken of by you,
for they do not need it, where
political pull is strong enough.
The regulation is daily violated
for political friends, but is
iron-clad against unfortunates
like myself. I am almost
sorry that you mentioned this
to Lawrence, since it only
raises false hopes. I have
advised him to remain just
where he is & to improve
every opportunity in study.
I am so glad that he called
on you and Mrs. Kean. He
has just written us how
much he enjoyed his visit.
His health so far has been
remarkably good, & if he can
only continue well, we will
be perfectly content with his
situation. I sincerely hope that
when your tour of duty as
Chief Surgeon is over, that the
S. G. will send you back to
Boston. He will give you
a good station, I feel sure.
Why didn't you come on & tell what
you know about canned beef?
There are not less than 20 members
of the Corps before the Board, at present.
The S. G. gave them a little “Blow-out”
at his house, a few evenings ago.
We missed the Chief Surgeon
of the 7th Corps.

Please present my
warmest regards to Mrs. Kean &
a kiss to dear little Martha.

I shall never forget your
many acts of kindness to my boy.
div1.closer:
Affectionately, yours, Walter Reed. Col. J.R. Kean, U.S.A.
Camp Columbia,
Havana.
